Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk ipa-admintools
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: ipa bug fix update
Vulnerability.Description: Red Hat Identity Management is a centralized authentication, identity management and authorization solution for both traditional and cloud-based enterprise environments. It integrates components of the Red Hat Directory Server, MIT Kerberos, Red Hat Certificate System, NTP, and DNS. It provides web browser and command-line interfaces. Its administration tools allow an administrator to quickly install, set up, and administer a group of domain controllers to meet the authentication and identity management requirements of large-scale Linux and UNIX deployments. This update fixes the following bugs: Previously, when no closest AD domain controller was found, adding an AD trust relationship with Identity Management Server could fail with an error message. A patch has been applied to address this bug, and a trust relationship can be established as expected by using a domain controller from any available Active Directory site. (BZ#1143779) Previously, when establishing cross-forest trust, a domain controller without PDC role could have been selected, leading Active Directory domain controller to reject updates to the trust topology. As a consequence, no authentication was possible towards Red Hat Identity Management, and no users and groups from Active Directory were available. With this update, cross-forest trust is established only to domain controllers of the forest's root domain with the primary domain controller emulator role. As a result, a proper error message is now displayed in the described situation, and domain controllers of the forest root domain are filtered to only use PDC-capable ones. (BZ#1144030) Prior to this update, Red Hat Identity Management was unable to trust certain domains within a complex Active Directory forest topology. Consequently, users from certain domains beyond Active Directory forest root domain were unable to access resources provided by Red Hat Identity Management. This update improves logic to filter out Active Directory domains which cannot be supported through cross-forest AD trusts in order to allow a wider set of forest-domain relationships. As a result, users from Active Directory domains can access resources provided by Red Hat Identity Management through a cross-forest trust link. (BZ#1144031) Users of Red Hat Identity Management are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
